-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	Ellay
Date: 	Sat, 14 Nov 2020 00:20:39 +0000
From: 	Amazon.com <vfe-campaign-response@amazon.com>
To: 	us@oddballauthors.com

Looking for something in Teen & Young Adult Science Fiction & Fantasy?

	

Amazon.com 
<https://www.amazon.com/gp/r.html?C=RU2KJ6FL7SPL&K=2P4UR7V96S3F7&M=urn:rtn:msg:20201114002039b0cae4483ab045f28381073397b0p0na&R=2G1L9I070JX6Z&T=C&U=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.amazon.com%2Fref%3Dpe_27541010_550707390_sef_logo&H=EV4VQHSHURBEM3NDG9N2YSSHBOAA&ref_=pe_27541010_550707390_sef_logo>

date: Sun, 27 Dec 2020 02:10:28 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: <reddotvan@icloud.com>
subject: News of the Todd

Body:
Hi Geoff,

As usual your Xmas missive beat my vague "I should write Geoff" by a 
long shot.

Congratulations on being a double grandfather!  And you got to see them 
both!  All good.

You know, for years now it's struck me that you have a marvelously 
humorous writing style.  If you ever thought of picking up a new hobby, 
writing humorous pieces would be a boon to the world.

Naturally, I've been reading a fair bit.  Writing a lot less than normal 
because of the "covid cloud."

This whole thing with the soon-to-be ex-President is rather appalling.  
I wish someone would provide us with quantified data on how much the 
Russians influenced the 2016 election.  We know they worked at it just 
as we know they worked to help the Leave part of Brexit (which will go 
down in history as just as major a self-inflicted wound as our 2016 
elections).

I've signed up for a lot of Domestika online art classes. I'm taking one 
on Photoshop and, despite years of experience, I am learning things 
about Photoshop that I didn't know.  I've signed up for the Advanced 
Photoshop course by the same instructor, as well as a nice class on 
cover design by a German woman who speaks passable English.

The twins -- my writing partners -- are both still alive which, given 
what's been going on with Brit (the alpha of the two) and her health is 
actually saying quite a lot.  We think the root problem for her is some 
sort of auto-immune disease but we haven't got it down to specifics. Her 
hemiplegic migraines are nearly synonymous with strokes (sigh).  She's a 
tough lady but these past four years have been physically exhausting for 
her.  What seems to be helping most now is an acupuncturist who is using 
herbals to calm her nerves (literally, nice big needles go to nerve nexi).

I'm thinking that "this too shall pass" and we'll see the end of the 
COVID tunnel but perhaps not fully until 2022 (sigh).  Our ancestors 
survived much worse... although that's scant comfort.

One thing I have grown to realize is how incredibly powerful an 
individual human being is.  Take Greta Thunberg as an example. In fact, 
take anyone who decides that they will change things (Rosa Parks, the 
students in Tienanmen Square).  I wonder why we fail to use our strength 
so often?  Is it because changing the world is pretty consuming passion 
and we choose to avoid it?

I also am in shock that too many of my fellow countrymen (and women) are 
willing to accept a con man for President and cede unto him all the 
powers of a dictator.  I really have a hard time adjusting to how *dumb* 
these people are.  It makes me very sad.

I recall reading an article not too long ago praising some young black 
kids for their genius IQs. It wasn't the color of their skin that 
intrigued me -- it was that one of the kids scored a 142 on the 
Stanford-Binet IQ test.  I scored a 156 at the same age.  That made it 
really strike home that I am genius (gush, shucks, folks!).  I have 
always held the belief that everyone on this planet is as empowered as I 
am; that given the right set of circumstances, they could accomplish 
whatever they set their minds to, that we were universal in our 
potential.  Now, with the whole mess of the last four years, I have to 
question that and that has been causing me a great deal of angst.

Television-wise, I am now particularly spoiled.  I acquired a marvelous 
ASUS 34" ProArt curved monitor which now graces my desk in my bedroom.  
Over the holidays I acquired a Amazon Roku Firestick and discovered that 
I can pipe TV signals through my HDMI2 port.  So I've been getting 4k TV 
from 18 inches. Whew!

I've been watching the new Star Trek Discovery.  The first season nearly 
killed it for me because every episode pretty much stopped dead when the 
Klingons came on.  Season Two was better and now Season Three is quite 
enjoyable (forgiving such complete inanity as "parasitic ice").

I watched the Mandolorian with a skeptical eye particularly as so much 
of it was just pure re-cast western. And there was one episode that 
stopped me for weeks but I was assured that things got better.

I've also been re-watching Dr. Who, starting with Eccleston who was such 
a marvelous Doctor.  I'm sorry he couldn't stick around longer (but 
maybe he would have gone stale).

Anyway, that's a taste of life at Dell Ridge.

Always glad to hear from you, my oldest friend!

Love,

Todd

We should talk.

FYI

-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	Re: Reader guidelines or Magpie’s War
Date: 	Thu, 18 Mar 2021 12:43:12 -1000
From: 	Stephanie Gayron <sgteach14@att.net>
To: 	todd <todd@toddwriter.com>

Hi Todd,
I wanted to let you know how much I am enjoying Magpie’s War. I am 60% 
finished which I am sure you are disappointed in my progress as I am, 
but I am busy here and my reading is usually only in the evening. 
Everything works. For me the middle of the book is the most gripping as 
the story moves along much more quickly than the beginning. I am sure 
this is because the reader is being introduced to the characters and the 
setting. We are in Maui now and as I write, I am reading. Question about 
ley lines. Please clarify what they are and the significance in the 
story, since the closest I can come is Wikipedia- Ley (landform) name 
for a crag, rock of cliff in the North German language area.

Stephanie
Keep your eyes on eternity!

date: Wed, 17 Feb 2021 09:00:51 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Pamela Melroy<pamela.a.melroy@gmail.com>
subject: Oh my goodness!

Body:
Pam,

I hope this is still a good email address.

In looking back, I realize that it's been THREE YEARS since I last spoke 
to you!  I think perhaps I took the whole "Pam's busy, don't bother her" 
thinking a bit too far.

I hope you're doing well.

I'm in Las Vegas these days and hanging in there.

Recently I've come to the notion that we're going to need rotating 
centripetal-gravity producing stations to survive in space (of course, 
whether the moon's gravity would be sufficient remains to be explored.)  
This brought me back to the whole Gerard K O'Neill's Space Settlements 
publication (it was a NASA SP at one point).

I noticed that DARPA has just recently announced NOM4D which sounds like 
a good start on space manufacturing (it seems like something that might 
have your fingerprints on it).

I'm in the process of writing the President to suggest that we need a 
new great challenge for our nation and believe that the time is ripe to 
push fully into space... and staying there.

I was wondering if you had any thoughts on that or pointers to thoughts.

I'm also trying to build a near term science fiction story line based on 
this (sorta Space Cadet but for the 21st century).  I had an "aliens 
invade" dystopian idea set on the asteroid belt (called "Minor's War" 
because it's a YA about asteroid miners taking back Earth) but my heart 
is never really in dystopian/apocalyptic stories.

A proper rotating space station would also be a great place to learn how 
to properly create self-sustaining environmental systems.  Also, we 
really need to start to learn how to build stuff in space instead of 
simply boosting it pre-built from Earth.

Anyway, I hope you're well, challenged, and happy!

Cheers,

Todd McCaffrey

Cheers,

Todd

Hi Joni,

I've been asked to help out with the 20BooksTo50k booth (display?) for WotF.

I'm presuming that books will be sent for us to show/sell/giveaway.

Could I ask that a pair of 36 & 37 be sent along as well for /moi//?/  I

from them, so if you want to send even *more* along to me, that'd be great!

Cheers,

Todd

Body:
I think this was meant for you!

-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	Post-SSWS 2022 Survey
Date: 	Wed, 16 Feb 2022 16:01:58 +0000
From: 	Marie Whittaker & Mark Lefebvre <noreply@regfox.com>
Reply-To: 	Marie Whittaker & Mark Lefebvre 
<superstarswritingdirector@gmail.com>
To: 	todd@toddwriter.com

Post-SSWS 2022 Survey

Thank you for attending our 12th Superstars Writing Seminars!

It was our biggest and best event to date, thanks in part to your 
feedback on past conferences.

We want SSWS 2023 to be even better. To help us make this happen, please 
fill out our brief survey. Your experiences, opinions, and comments 
really matter! We read every single one and take each suggestion into 
consideration, so don’t miss the opportunity to help shape next year's 
event.

Please go to this LINK (https://forms.gle/f4ZiQu2BFccjfkW77 
<https://api.webconnex.com/v1/postmaster/track/click/7215e7e9bf3b401d8e18e4226aee9590/85b4933b8f4111ec9d740243a424b527?url=https%3A%2F%2Fforms.gle%2Ff4ZiQu2BFccjfkW77>) 
and fill out the survey *before Friday, March 4th*.

If you choose to include your email address, you will be entered in a 
drawing for A FREE CRAFT DAY at SSWS 2023.

(/Please note that if you include your email address, only the survey 
administrator will be aware of your identity—no identifying information 
will be included in the data analyses or shared with the planning 
committee/)

In addition to the survey, we are *always *open to feedback and would 
love to hear from you.

Thank you again for being a part of Superstars 2022! Making cherished 
connections with our growing Tribe is always a favorite part of this 
annual event. You’re what makes these seminars magic. Keep learning and 
networking. Keep in touch with your Tribe. And most of all, keep writing.

Marie Whittaker & Mark Leslie Lefebvre
Superstars Writing Seminars Directors

Don't want to receive further communication? Click here 
<https://ssws.account.webconnex.com/unsubscribe/regfox.com/7215e7e9bf3b401d8e18e4226aee9590/85b4933b8f4111ec9d740243a424b527> 
to unsubscribe.

date: Sun, 27 Dec 2020 02:10:28 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: <reddotvan@icloud.com>
subject: News of the Todd

Body:
Hi Geoff,

As usual your Xmas missive beat my vague "I should write Geoff" by a 
long shot.

Congratulations on being a double grandfather!  And you got to see them 
both!  All good.

You know, for years now it's struck me that you have a marvelously 
humorous writing style.  If you ever thought of picking up a new hobby, 
writing humorous pieces would be a boon to the world.

Naturally, I've been reading a fair bit.  Writing a lot less than normal 
because of the "covid cloud."

This whole thing with the soon-to-be ex-President is rather appalling.  
I wish someone would provide us with quantified data on how much the 
Russians influenced the 2016 election.  We know they worked at it just 
as we know they worked to help the Leave part of Brexit (which will go 
down in history as just as major a self-inflicted wound as our 2016 
elections).

I've signed up for a lot of Domestika online art classes. I'm taking one 
on Photoshop and, despite years of experience, I am learning things 
about Photoshop that I didn't know.  I've signed up for the Advanced 
Photoshop course by the same instructor, as well as a nice class on 
cover design by a German woman who speaks passable English.

The twins -- my writing partners -- are both still alive which, given 
what's been going on with Brit (the alpha of the two) and her health is 
actually saying quite a lot.  We think the root problem for her is some 
sort of auto-immune disease but we haven't got it down to specifics. Her 
hemiplegic migraines are nearly synonymous with strokes (sigh).  She's a 
tough lady but these past four years have been physically exhausting for 
her.  What seems to be helping most now is an acupuncturist who is using 
herbals to calm her nerves (literally, nice big needles go to nerve nexi).

I'm thinking that "this too shall pass" and we'll see the end of the 
COVID tunnel but perhaps not fully until 2022 (sigh).  Our ancestors 
survived much worse... although that's scant comfort.

One thing I have grown to realize is how incredibly powerful an 
individual human being is.  Take Greta Thunberg as an example. In fact, 
take anyone who decides that they will change things (Rosa Parks, the 
students in Tienanmen Square).  I wonder why we fail to use our strength 
so often?  Is it because changing the world is pretty consuming passion 
and we choose to avoid it?

I also am in shock that too many of my fellow countrymen (and women) are 
willing to accept a con man for President and cede unto him all the 
powers of a dictator.  I really have a hard time adjusting to how *dumb* 
these people are.  It makes me very sad.

I recall reading an article not too long ago praising some young black 
kids for their genius IQs. It wasn't the color of their skin that 
intrigued me -- it was that one of the kids scored a 142 on the 
Stanford-Binet IQ test.  I scored a 156 at the same age.  That made it 
really strike home that I am genius (gush, shucks, folks!).  I have 
always held the belief that everyone on this planet is as empowered as I 
am; that given the right set of circumstances, they could accomplish 
whatever they set their minds to, that we were universal in our 
potential.  Now, with the whole mess of the last four years, I have to 
question that and that has been causing me a great deal of angst.

Television-wise, I am now particularly spoiled.  I acquired a marvelous 
ASUS 34" ProArt curved monitor which now graces my desk in my bedroom.  
Over the holidays I acquired a Amazon Roku Firestick and discovered that 
I can pipe TV signals through my HDMI2 port.  So I've been getting 4k TV 
from 18 inches. Whew!

I've been watching the new Star Trek Discovery.  The first season nearly 
killed it for me because every episode pretty much stopped dead when the 
Klingons came on.  Season Two was better and now Season Three is quite 
enjoyable (forgiving such complete inanity as "parasitic ice").

I watched the Mandolorian with a skeptical eye particularly as so much 
of it was just pure re-cast western. And there was one episode that 
stopped me for weeks but I was assured that things got better.

I've also been re-watching Dr. Who, starting with Eccleston who was such 
a marvelous Doctor.  I'm sorry he couldn't stick around longer (but 
maybe he would have gone stale).

Anyway, that's a taste of life at Dell Ridge.

Always glad to hear from you, my oldest friend!

Love,

Todd

Hi Sherri! [RESCHEDULED]

I have author and Writers of the Future judge, Todd 
McCaffrey, confirmed for a pre-recorded phone interview on your show, 
"Chatting with Sherri," on Wednesday, January 27th at 1:00 PM Pacific 
for about 30 - 45 minutes.

*This will be a Skype call,...*

*Todd's Skype username: **live:todd427_1*

*Sherri's Skype username: rithebard*

As backup, I have Todd's cell number as 818.324.5127 and I have your 
cell phone number as 619.654.2150.

As Galaxy Press is the publisher for the anthology, /*L. Ron Hubbard 
Presents Writers of the Future */I trust there will be some opportunity 
to *mention the full title of the book *as well as the website, 
www.WritersOfTheFuture.com <http://www.writersofthefuture.com/>.

Talking Points,...

1) Todd's judging of the stories for *L. Ron Hubbard Presents Writers of 
the Future Volume 36 and Volume 37*.

2) Tood's career and what he's currently working on.

3) Mention the website (www.WritersOfTheFuture.com 
<http://www.writersofthefuture.com/>) to give other writers and 
illustrators the opportunity to enter the contest (contest rules are on 
the site) and purchase the book.

4) Promote Todd's own site: *pernhome.com/tjm/ 
<http://pernhome.com/tjm/> **and www.WritersOfTheFuture.com 
<http://www.writersofthefuture.com/>*

*(See bio below.)*

*
*

If you have any questions, please feel free to contact me directly, 
323.574.5916 <tel:323.574.5916>.

Thanks,

Carmen

Mr. Carmen Bartolo

Media Relations

Galaxy Press

323.574.5916 <tel:323.574.5916>

MediaRelationsCarmen@gmail.com <mailto:MediaRelationsCarmen@gmail.com>

www.GalaxyPress.com <http://www.galaxypress.com/>

www.WritersOfTheFuture.com <http://www.writersofthefuture.com/>

<<<<<<

  TODD MCCAFFREY

Writer Judge – Biography

Todd McCaffrey was born to Anne McCaffrey on April 27th, 1956. The 
then-named Todd Johnson came into the world as a rather precocious 
middle child. Anyone who questions the precocious part has only to read 
some of the anecdotes in “Dragonholder” to have any doubt removed. He 
spent most of his childhood on the East Coast of the USA until moving to 
Dublin, Ireland with his mother and sister in 1970.

Like most of the boys growing up in the ’60s, McCaffrey became space 
mad. However, unlike most of the other young men running around their 
yards in pretend helmets and throwing toy rockets into the air, he was 
given a “complete” set of the actual Lunar Module Pilot Study Guides in 
1968. The number of hours spent devouring them repeatedly from cover to 
cover is evident in the fact that he has been known to quote excerpts 
from them during convention panels.

When the time came for him to pursue higher education, McCaffrey 
attended Lehigh University in Bethlehem, Pennsylvania, for a year—and 
hated it. But he did discover one of the great loves of his life while 
he was there, computers. He graduated with Honors—or rather, 
“Honours”—in 1985 from Trinity College, Dublin.

Having never lost his love for space, he left Ireland for Los Angeles, 
California, in the hopes of working in the aerospace industry. However, 
the computers got him first, and he began working in computer 
programming in 1986. He continued to develop his love of space and all 
mechanical things that fly by getting a private pilot’s license in 1988. 
One interesting side note is the collapse of the aerospace industry in 1989.

During this time, his interest in writing also took flight. The sale of 
some of his early short stories helped him log an impressive amount of 
airtime. He flew across the continent solo in 1989, attending Oshkosh 
along the way. After quitting his day job in 1990 to write full time, he 
repeated his solo cross-continent flight and attended the 1990 Oshkosh 
as well.

Todd McCaffrey became a Writers of the Future judge in 2011.

    /“///The Writers of the Future is one of the premier awards that’s
    available particularly to new writers. It’s basically the only one
    there. This is a chance to open up the universe to reward people who
    are trying and striving and succeeding in creating great stories, to
    reward them with more than just a pat on the back to actually some
    monetary reward and some recognition and to give them a leg up into
    the world of a professional writer.///” /—Todd McCaffrey

Find out more at: pernhome.com/tjm/ <http://pernhome.com/tjm/>

Subject: Fwd: For Your Consideration Project Blue Book: The Game by Steven-Elliot Altman

Body:
FYI :)

-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	For Your Consideration Project Blue Book: The Game by 
Steven-Elliot Altman
Date: 	Thu, 11 Feb 2021 04:31:01 +0500
From: 	Steve Altman <steve@socialimpulse.com>
To: 	todd@toddwriter.com

Hey Todd,

Steve Altman here. Hope this email finds you well, it's been awhile, and 
I pray we all get to meet up at conventions again. <sigh>

In the meantime, please forgive my shameless promotion here. I'm gunning 
for recommendations for my last History channel videogame, /Project Blue 
Book/ with little or no guidance and have drummed up this post on the 
SFWA board. For amplification purposes I am sending it out to certain 
SFWA members who may be interested in playing and/or reading the game's 
script for consideration. Hope you won't mind being on my list. Did you 
happen to catch the TV series? Well worth watching.

Here is an overview of *Project Blue Book: The Game* with the attached 
game script for your consideration (as well as some smaller samples) and 
links to play the game for free. Enjoy!

The information below has been posted in its entirety on the Members 
Only SFWA message boards at the following link, and should be treated 
confidentially: 
https://www.sfwa.org/forum/topic/15951-project-blue-book-the-game-by-steven-elliot-altman-and-julie-marsh/ 
<https://www.sfwa.org/forum/topic/15951-project-blue-book-the-game-by-steven-elliot-altman-and-julie-marsh/>

Project Blue Book The Game Image 2.png

Project Blue Book: The Game by Steven-Elliot Altman and Julie Marsh

Please find attached the Final Production Draft of Project Blue Book: 
The Game, which I wrote for A&E Networks based on their History Channel 
series, along with my clue writer Julie Marsh (Julie was not credited on 
the game itself, as I was featured, but I am compelled to include her 
for consideration due to her essential contributions).

I was attempting to bring the genres of television writing and videogame 
writing one step closer. I was given nearly free reign by the network 
and showrunners on how to proceed, and so decided to write my own 
adaptations of half the game's cases based on produced episodes of the 
TV series (with additional scenes that I envisioned) and the other half 
of the cases as original cases which I based on actual declassified 
U.S.A.F Project Blue Book files.

The Production Draft encompasses all 9 Cases of Season One of the game. 
Because this document is quite lengthy I have also attached "Case 105: 
The Aztec Recovery" (in which I introduce J. Robert Oppenheimer to the 
game's story) and "Case 107: Project Rainbow" (in which I 
introduce Albert Einstein to the game's story, in a story previously 
dramatized as the feature film /The Philadelphia Experiment/) as two 
smaller samples of the complete work.

Besides the script, the game is FREE TO PLAY as a mobile app available 
for both IOS and Android phones and tablets in the safe links listed 
below, and I invite you to play!

Project Blue Book: The Game on IOS 
<https://apps.apple.com/us/app/project-blue-book-the-game/id1445162277>

Project Blue Book: The Game on Android 
<https://play.google.com/store/apps/details?id=com.threegates.projectbluebook&hl=en_US>

And for anyone who does not wish to actually play the game, here are 
two youtube videos posted by players that depict the game's opening 
tutorial, and the start of CASE 101, The Fuller Dogfight.

Project Blue Book Opening Cut Scene and Tutorial 
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=UFhBUpUeqsE&t=5s>

Project Blue Book Case 101 Walkthrough 
<https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=OOhAgdjG7bY&t=23s>

And finally, here is the approved description from the app store:

Project Blue Book: The Game is the official, free-to-play, hidden object 
adventure game based on HISTORY’s hit drama series PROJECT BLUE BOOK, 
created by David O'Leary, and executive produced by Academy Award and 
Golden Globe® winner Robert Zemeckis. The series explores the 
historical, Top Secret investigations into UFOs conducted by the U.S. 
Air Force between 1952 and 1969.

In Project Blue Book: The Game, you will start off as a newly recruited 
agent in Project Blue Book during the 1950s, under the guidance of the 
show's lead investigators, Dr. J. Allen Hynek (played by Aidan Gillen 
from “Game Of Thrones”), and Captain Michael Quinn (played by Michael 
Malarkey from “The Vampire Diaries”), and begin to investigate real 
declassified UFO investigations to find the truth!

Hundreds of puzzles, witness interviews and hidden object scenes will 
challenge your observation and deduction tactics as you investigate 
alongside your favorite characters into many of the cases you loved from 
the series, uncover exclusive new content, and explore new cases that 
can only be found in the game! The game's story is written by 
bestselling science-fiction writer and award-winning game writer 
Steven-Elliot Altman, best known for similar social games like PEARL’S 
PERIL and ANCIENT ALIENS.

We're here to find the truth! So, come help us investigate flying 
saucers along with Dr. Hynek in the world's first Unidentified Flying 
(Hidden) Object Game!

Thank you for considering *Project Blue Book: The Game* for a Nebula 
Nomination in the best game writing category. Should you wish to 
nominate it, here is the SFWA link: https://www.sfwa.org/forum/ballots/ 
<https://www.sfwa.org/forum/ballots/>

Love and light to you and your family,
Steve

*Steven-Elliot Altman*
Chief Executive Officer

  Phone  +1 (323) 708-9005
  Fax       +1 (877) 581-8750
  Site Socialimpulse.com <http://Socialimpulse.com>

Body:
-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	Re: A/C woes
Date: 	Thu, 17 Jun 2021 12:00:14 -0700
From: 	Kenneth Lee <klee10026@gmail.com>
To: 	todd <todd@toddwriter.com>

Hi Todd,

I am sorry you still have issues with the AC unit. I thought the last 
time Hot Cold Air came out, they had fixed all the problems.

I have forwarded your message to them and asked for a solution. 
Hopefully they can send a knowledgeable technician to take care of it 
once for all. I will keep you posted.

----------------
Best Regards,
Kenneth
(702) 580-0968
klee10026@gmail.com <mailto:klee10026@gmail.com>

On Wed, Jun 16, 2021 at 8:42 PM todd <todd@toddwriter.com 
<mailto:todd@toddwriter.com>> wrote:

    Dear Mr Lee,

    I would like to request someone to fix the A/C. Here is the situation.
    The A/C system is one condenser with two internal thermostats, one
    upstairs and one down stairs. There is a damper, which is movable flap
    inside the duct work that directs air flow downstair or upstairs
    depending on the settings of the thermostat.

    At some point in time in the past one of the thermostats was
    disconnected and so the damper does not adjust airflow, since there is
    only one thermostat attached.

    I would like to get the second thermostat reconnected and confirm the
    damper is working correctly to cool both floors as soon as possible.

    As it is right now, the AC is running continuously. Even when the
    system
    is turned OFF, the fans still run. When the system is set to COOL, the
    thermostat setting downstairs has no effect -- and the system runs
    continuously, without regards to temperature (the temperature has been
    68 when the thermostat was set to 72), nothing short of turning the AC
    to OFF on the thermostat effects that (and, as I said, even then the
    fans continue to run). None of this can be good for the AC system.

    At this very moment, my room temperature is 79.3 degrees which is
    intolerable.

    I look forward to hearing from you immediately.

    Sincerely,
    Todd McCaffrey

date: Tue, 12 May 2020 08:52:51 -0700
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Janis Ian<janisian@earthlink.net>
subject: Hello from Vegas!

Body:
Hi Janis,

I hope you're doing well but I worry about you being in Florida.

I am now 64 (unbelievable!) but it really doesn't feel all that much 
different from 60.

We've been hunkered down -- we self-isolated pretty early as we're all 
high-risk (asthma, diabetes, age, etc.) so we've been holding up just fine.

Who'd'a thunk that face masks would be all the rage in 2020?  Not that 
their efficaciousness is all that great but every little bit helps.

The COVID-19 thing had me pretty rattled for a while but I'm getting 
over it.  Not so much the dying part but just the whole strangeness of 
it all.
It made me realize how lucky we've been in the 20th century.  We'd 
gotten complacent about our health and longevity.  I imagine that's 
going to change.

Anyway, dealing with that slowed me on writing for a bit (also, not 
being able to write in Starbucks).

Do you read Kindle format or do you want PDF or DOC for reading?  I know 
I offered to send you some reading material, I forgot to ask about the 
format.

I've been playing with a bunch of Native Instruments software and 
hardware (picked up their 32-key keyboard, and their cool Maschine pad) 
as well as making art and writing (the all round creative).

Anyway, that's about all the news that's fit to print.
Cheers,
Todd

messages.content:
Classify the email’s primary intent as one of: request, status, intro, invoice, scheduling, marketing, support, personal, other. Return a single word.

Subject: Audio Work

Body:
Hi Angel!

So... there are two projects:

1. Cloud Conqueror (Twin Soul Series #2)

2. The Jupiter Game (that's me)

The idea is:

1. Convert from manuscript to "screenplay" (really, radio play-ish) format.

2. Create audio suitable for ACX.

I've already done a full audiobook with ELLAY (and it's making money!!) 
which is why I think this might be a good idea.

I'm willing to pay for the conversion, the output to be in FinalDraft 12 
format (.fdx) but, of course, if I think the price is too high, I'll do 
it myself.

For the audio stuff, the going rate is $250 PFH (per finished hour) 
which, quite simply, I can't afford (which is why I was the sole voice 
for ELLAY). However, perhaps a royalty share?

You can get a 30-day trial of FinalDraft here <https://finaldraft.com/>. 
After that, if things work out, I might include the cost of you getting 
it in our deal.

Attached are the 1 page original and 1 page script format to give you an 
idea of what I want.  The way I handle it, I create SIDES so that I can 
read each voice separately, then the "general description" is what I 
read as the narrator. (You wouldn't want to go from the "screenplay" 
that I produce to the screen without editing, that's for sure! <grin>).

Anyway, take a look, let me know if you (and y'all) might be interested!

Love,

Todd

date: Wed, 17 Feb 2021 09:00:51 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Pamela Melroy<pamela.a.melroy@gmail.com>
subject: Oh my goodness!

Body:
Pam,

I hope this is still a good email address.

In looking back, I realize that it's been THREE YEARS since I last spoke 
to you!  I think perhaps I took the whole "Pam's busy, don't bother her" 
thinking a bit too far.

I hope you're doing well.

I'm in Las Vegas these days and hanging in there.

Recently I've come to the notion that we're going to need rotating 
centripetal-gravity producing stations to survive in space (of course, 
whether the moon's gravity would be sufficient remains to be explored.)  
This brought me back to the whole Gerard K O'Neill's Space Settlements 
publication (it was a NASA SP at one point).

I noticed that DARPA has just recently announced NOM4D which sounds like 
a good start on space manufacturing (it seems like something that might 
have your fingerprints on it).

I'm in the process of writing the President to suggest that we need a 
new great challenge for our nation and believe that the time is ripe to 
push fully into space... and staying there.

I was wondering if you had any thoughts on that or pointers to thoughts.

I'm also trying to build a near term science fiction story line based on 
this (sorta Space Cadet but for the 21st century).  I had an "aliens 
invade" dystopian idea set on the asteroid belt (called "Minor's War" 
because it's a YA about asteroid miners taking back Earth) but my heart 
is never really in dystopian/apocalyptic stories.

A proper rotating space station would also be a great place to learn how 
to properly create self-sustaining environmental systems.  Also, we 
really need to start to learn how to build stuff in space instead of 
simply boosting it pre-built from Earth.

Anyway, I hope you're well, challenged, and happy!

Cheers,

Todd McCaffrey

from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Todd McCaffrey<todd427@gmail.com>
subject: Fwd: Oh Shit

Body:
-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	Oh Shit
Date: 	Tue, 19 Oct 2021 02:45:11 +0100
From: 	Geoff Hilton <reddotvan@icloud.com>
To: 	todd <todd@toddwriter.com>

Oh Shit
Really really sorry to hear that, for a few years in London we were 
Irish Exciles, crap jobs (me rather than Alan who was going places) and 
not much money but London had some pretty fun times too. What the fuck 
happened. ? Any ideas ? Do you have Susan and/or the elder sister’s 
address (senior moment re name). Last time I tracked Alan he was selling 
LandRover cars in USA i think.
This is cropping up too frequently for my liking !!
Our friends/family/crowd here have fared ok re Covid but other 
things/shit happens and Funerals have been closed door affairs with only 
a handful of people allowed to gather. Good Friends have been lost, some 
are pretty sick still.
Annette and I lost touch then I found out she died but ofcourse that a 
few years back now

Hope you well, and Gigi too. Up until a month ago I was A1 subject to 
the odd few days manflu once every couple of years. It wasnt covid but I 
was getting a but concerned … ok now thanks to the Doc I finally went to 
see … some heavy duty ABs and am starting to read long books again. 
Still got some blood tests later this week. But all good considering the 
alternative. Small beer really but it has focused my mind.
Am a Facetime/Zoom Grandad … now 2 Grandkids in … Mason in Holland and 
Emily in Melbourne Oz. Seen a little bit of Mason since the dutch let us 
in a couple of months ago. We were in Oz when Emily was born. Had 
tickets to the GrandPrix then almost overnight the shutters came down in 
Oz and we were lucky to have seats back to UK (19 hours Perth 
Heathrow!). Atleast I had the sense and insurance cover to reroute as 
the original plan was via HongKong which seems such a good idea in Feb2020.
Nice car, enjoy the drive, pleased you are prospering Don’t let it do 
the driving !
Stay safe but happy and boldly go etc

Bit Gutted
Geoff

Ps on a happier note and maybe I mentioned last time but i met up with 
Henry Dagg, must be mid/late 2019. Will send you a recent youtuvr video 
link that seems to have been late covid times here. His workshop hasn’t 
changed and I still owe him for breaking a string on his Bork toured 
giant music box

Pps … When i sent you the email I had been dreaming of getting the old 
band together (the one that never was !) .. too late now.
Finally …. Still got the off grid barn high in the French Pyreenees and 
have managed since Sept 2019 just 1 trip out 6 weeks ago when the French 
started to open up.

Sent from my iPhone

date: Sun, 22 Aug 2021 11:29:54 -0700
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Todd McCaffrey<todd427@gmail.com>
subject: Fwd: How's it going?

Body:
-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	Re: How's it going?
Date: 	Sun, 22 Aug 2021 06:03:07 +0100
From: 	Georgeanne Kennedy <squeej51g@gmail.com>
To: 	todd <todd@toddwriter.com>

Ah, sweetie! It’s lovely of you to check in, and probably couldn’t come 
at a better time.
You asked, so I ain’t gonna hold back. Tune in your big brother 
listening ears cause your baby sister needs sound advice. I have to 
admit, I’m not doing too well. Wish I could fluff away, all light and 
breezy, and tell you ‘I’m grand’ but I’m not. I guess it’s a combination 
of things but, predominantly, living on my own, away from the area I’ve 
known for over 40 years, is incredibly hard and seems to magnify any 
other difficult issues I experience in my life as a single 60-something. 
It’s like I’m starting all over again, when I’m already starting over 
again since my marriage ended. The property market here is a mess, with 
houses selling far above asking price because there’s a scarcity of 
stock for sale, so I can’t afford to buy anything now and lay down new 
roots. The holding pattern I’m in is excruciating!

And I guess other aspects of my life, and the seemingly never-ending 
crises that are engulfing the earth, are all mixing together to fill my 
plate with a gloomy looking repast. I should stop reading the news.

Sleep is difficult; I’ve been wide awake for an hour and it’s not yet 
5am, so this day’s store of resilience is already fecked up. - I have to 
go to Owen’s girlfriend’s place today to help celebrate the “gender 
reveal” (slap me quick before I gag!) they have planned now that their 
gestating baby is 3 months along. It’ll be the first time I’ll be in the 
same air space as Geoff since we were in court getting our divorce 
decree; when I bawled my eyes out in front of everyone whilst giving 
testimony. Oy! Added to that, Owen has, frankly, been treating me like a 
piece of shit over the last few months so the strain is telling. I’ll be 
a big girl, though, go along to see what sex the baby will be and try to 
smile a lot.

About two weeks ago Geoff’s youngest sister, Edel, the main carer for my 
(ex?) mother-in-law, Joan, was in a terrible car crash while travelling 
to Cork for a weekend break with her boyfriend. She’s broken the bones 
in the top of her foot, and two vertebrae just above the tailbone. She 
literally broke her arse. Poor Mick, her boyfriend, is far worse off and 
will remain in hospital in Cork for at least another 6 weeks, undergoing 
another couple of surgeries on top of the 3 he’s already had. Fuck! What 
a nightmare, and no visitors allowed to see him. Poor guy.

And then a totally strange series of things have occurred recently with 
regard to my late sister-in-law’s husband, Noel. He’s a very successful 
businessman and a pub owner and has been trying to cope with the sudden 
death of his wife in June 2019, along with the grief their two (young) 
adult kids are experiencing, plus the lack of pub business due to Covid.

I’ve kept in loose touch with Noel ever since he asked me to write and 
deliver Maria’s eulogy. Over the last couple of years, through texts, 
he’s always suggested that we get together for a drink and catch up 
which I’ve always put down as pure politeness. Recently he suggested the 
same thing but in a phone call when he told me about Edel’s crash, which 
no one else in the Kennedy clan had informed me of.

Edel has always been close to Noel and she asked him to drive to Cork to 
be with her whilst she gave an official report to the Gardai regarding 
the crash. So here’s where it gets weird, Tig. Noel asked me to drive 
with him to Cork to collect Edel but suggested we go down the day before 
her release, have a nice meal, a few drinks and “a laugh”, and stay the 
night in an hotel before we retrieve Edel the following day. Whilst he 
was suggesting this plan I was uncommonly quiet on the other end of the 
phone and Noel said we would, of course, have separate rooms because he 
“wasn’t going to try and climb into bed with me”. The thought never 
crossed my mind! To be honest, I wasn’t sure what the fuck was going on 
but it’s been a very long time since I’ve been in the company of a kind 
man who wanted to hang out with me, so I agreed, thinking what harm 
could come of it.

At any rate, as it turned out, Edel didn’t have to have an interview 
with the Gardai in Cork and without discussing it with me, Noel changed 
his initial plan ‘to have a laugh’, and we simply drove to and from Cork 
on the same day to collect Edel. I reckon he possibly had a good think 
about what he’d proposed and decided against it. We had a pleasant time 
talking on the way down to Cork but I couldn’t forget the fact that I’m 
fairly certain he’d possibly made a pass at me. Or did he? I have no clue.

So my silly girl head can’t stop thinking about this, and Noel. In fact, 
it’s wrecking my head, and living alone doesn’t help; I already spend 
*way* too much time in my own head. I keep scolding myself to stop! but 
I’m lonely, and would like a man to like me again. I guess I’m just 
going to have to let time do it’s magical thing and allow it all to 
slowly fade away. Talk to me, Todd. Give me your take on this. Sorry 
this is so long but, hell! I’m long-winded.

Love,
Skin

Sent from my iPad

Body:
-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	WELCOME TO 101 SELF PUBLISHING
Date: 	Fri, 26 Mar 2021 17:09:28 -0400 (EDT)
From: 	Mark Dawson <mark@selfpublishingformula.com>
To: 	todd@toddwriter.com

Your Welcome Message from Mark Dawson
image

*Hello!*

A huge welcome to Self Publishing 101.

Self publishing can be complicated and confusing and I want this course 
to be your easy-to-follow and comprehensive guide to what you need to 
have in place in order to thrive as an independent author.

This email contains important information - please save it for future 
reference.

The course materials can be accessed at this address:

https://selfpublishingformula.com/mycourses 
<https://mo349.infusion-links.com/api/v1/click/4698703130132480/4946397635936256>

Please bookmark this link.

Once at the course directory, it's a good idea to visit 'START HERE' for 
a course orientation video. Once you’re done, dive straight into 101 by 
clicking on the 101 icon.

If that doesn't work, please check that you are logged in. You will see 
a 'Sign in' tab in the top right of the screen if you’re /not/ logged in.

You are entitled to join our ‘Genius' Facebook Group which is exclusive 
to paid students of this course. It is a valuable part of your enrolment 
and it should be your first port of call for any questions you have.

You can apply to join by clicking here 
<https://mo349.infusion-links.com/api/v1/click/5255644826959872/4946397635936256>. 
You'll be asked a question when you join, this helps our mods verify you 
are an enrolled student of 101. Here is the question and the response 
you should use:

Q. What is the name of James's new golden retriever puppy?

*A. Enzo*

You are also now a member of the Self Publishing Formula University 
(SPFU). This will include regular live webinars with instructional areas 
on the latest areas of interest for writers. Recordings of the webinars 
are available in the course directory area.

If you have any technical issues or problems with the course, you can 
try posting in Genius for answers or alternatively contact us direct via 
our support email:

support@selfpublishingformula.com <mailto:support@selfpublishingformula.com>

You are entitled to a great set of VIP Bonuses. Most will be issued via 
email (and posted in the course curriculum) around 17th May 2021. 
However, a few are available right away.

BOOKFUNNEL has fast become an essential tool for authors and we know you 
might want to get started right away. We are making the discount code 
available now. Click the following link for your exclusive offer, $50 
off your first year + a free month.

/https://bookfunnel.com/2021spring-sp101/ 
<https://mo349.infusion-links.com/api/v1/click/6470910051221504/4946397635936256>/

The offer expires on June 30th 2021.

You will also find a course exclusive bonus to PublisherRocket (covered 
in module 2, session 5), here: 
https://rocket.thrivecart.com/publisher-rocket-special/ 
<https://mo349.infusion-links.com/api/v1/click/5181103991816192/4946397635936256>

That's it for now. I'll be in the Genius group as much as I can, so 
please pop in and say hello!

It's great to have you onboard.

*Best wishes,*

*Mark.*

Profile Image 	*Mark Dawson*
Chief Scribbler
Self Publishing Formula Ltd
mark@selfpublishingformula.com
www.selfpublishingformula.com <http://www.selfpublishingformula.com>

Unsubscribe 
<https://mo349.infusionsoft.com/app/linkClick/77414/a3254b91eb5989c0/76336236/022159ef6266e532>

Self Publishing Formula Ltd Windover House St. Ann Street Salisbury, 
Wiltshire SP1 2DR United Kingdom

subject: Renewal for 7861 Dell Ridge Ave.

Body:
Mr. Lee

In these trying times we are all facing uncertainty. I would like to 
know if the owners intention is to re-lease the house, sell it or 
otherwise. I texted you last week requesting an update on releasing and 
have not received an answer, which is somewhat disconcerting. It is a 
very simple question which should not require much deliberation.

If the owners intention is to sell the home I am interested in 
discussing that option as well. Given the virus and all the 
ramifications I really need to know what is happening ASAP please.

Sincerely,

Todd McCaffrey

date: Mon, 04 Jan 2021 13:28:17 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Gigi Kennedy<gigi@pernhome.com>
subject: Re: Newses, nothing of great import

Body:
Good to hear from you!

Divorce is hard and is a major change. Moving is also a major change.  
Covid is a major change.  You've got a lot of stressors in your life.  
Recovering from a divorce takes about two years.

I started re-watching Dr. Who and Grey's Anatomy and Gilmore Girls as my 
covid fix.

I also had a blast watching "Enola Holmes" which confirmed my belief 
that Millie Bobby Brown is a terrific actor (the film spent a lot of 
time breaking the fourth wall in all sorts of marvelous manners).

I was severely disappointed with WW84. I didn't think all that much of 
Mandolorian either, although the ending was fun. I did have fun and do 
recommend the Apple TV show, "Home Before Dark." Seriously good acting 
all around.

I splurged and got myself a really nice 34" curved monitor and for 
Hannukah got a Amazon Roku firestick which means I get to watch 4k TV up 
close and personal.

New Year's Eve I took a shower and scratched an itchy ankle with the toe 
of my other foot -- and got it all infected.  By the second I was in an 
Urgent Care getting a prescription for Keflex which is a staph specific 
antibiotic.  I'm doing much better but I was appalled at how quickly the 
infection spread.

I am taking some Domestika courses, some on Photoshop, some on Book 
Cover Design, and all sorts of things.  They're mostly in Spanish with 
subtitles but I'm having fun.

I also signed up for Dean Wesley Smith's and Kristine Kathryn Rusch's 
"The Decade Ahead" bundle with the challenge of looking forward to 2029.

Dex and I speak semi-frequently.  He called me the other day to say that 
Jenna had totaled her car in a roll over accident.  I, of course, 
immediately recalled your Glen of the Downs accident.   She's okay but I 
asked her (via text) to be worried about possible concussions. (I 
attached a photo of her poor car.)

I don't know what's up with Alec.  He recently asked me if I still had 
"Mom's old chess set" and would I part with it.  I had Bami's old chess 
set which Bami very specifically willed to me and no, I was not going to 
part with it.

He does seem committed to being in the right about his incident in Texas 
which is alarmingly similar to the behavior of certain Presidents I 
could name.

Coming up soon, I get to apply for Medicare which is a bit more involved 
than I'd imagined.

I'm re-reading the /Bloody Jack/ series once again.  I started looking 
at the first book and just got caught up with the whole thing. It really 
was a lot of fun and it'd make a great TV series.

Here's hoping to a vaccinated New Year!

Love,
Todd

date: Wed, 16 Jun 2021 20:41:54 -0700
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Kenneth Lee<klee10026@gmail.com>
subject: A/C woes

Body:
Dear Mr Lee,

I would like to request someone to fix the A/C. Here is the situation. 
The A/C system is one condenser with two internal thermostats, one 
upstairs and one down stairs. There is a damper, which is movable flap 
inside the duct work that directs air flow downstair or upstairs 
depending on the settings of the thermostat.

At some point in time in the past one of the thermostats was 
disconnected and so the damper does not adjust airflow, since there is 
only one thermostat attached.

I would like to get the second thermostat reconnected and confirm the 
damper is working correctly to cool both floors as soon as possible.

As it is right now, the AC is running continuously. Even when the system 
is turned OFF, the fans still run. When the system is set to COOL, the 
thermostat setting downstairs has no effect -- and the system runs 
continuously, without regards to temperature (the temperature has been 
68 when the thermostat was set to 72), nothing short of turning the AC 
to OFF on the thermostat effects that (and, as I said, even then the 
fans continue to run). None of this can be good for the AC system.

At this very moment, my room temperature is 79.3 degrees which is 
intolerable.

I look forward to hearing from you immediately.

Sincerely,
Todd McCaffrey

date: Tue, 08 Mar 2022 11:35:53 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Angel Adams<angelinasvista@gmail.com>
subject: Audio Work

Body:
Hi Angel!

So... there are two projects:

1. Cloud Conqueror (Twin Soul Series #2)

2. The Jupiter Game (that's me)

The idea is:

1. Convert from manuscript to "screenplay" (really, radio play-ish) format.

2. Create audio suitable for ACX.

I've already done a full audiobook with ELLAY (and it's making money!!) 
which is why I think this might be a good idea.

I'm willing to pay for the conversion, the output to be in FinalDraft 12 
format (.fdx) but, of course, if I think the price is too high, I'll do 
it myself.

For the audio stuff, the going rate is $250 PFH (per finished hour) 
which, quite simply, I can't afford (which is why I was the sole voice 
for ELLAY). However, perhaps a royalty share?

You can get a 30-day trial of FinalDraft here <https://finaldraft.com/>. 
After that, if things work out, I might include the cost of you getting 
it in our deal.

Attached are the 1 page original and 1 page script format to give you an 
idea of what I want.  The way I handle it, I create SIDES so that I can 
read each voice separately, then the "general description" is what I 
read as the narrator. (You wouldn't want to go from the "screenplay" 
that I produce to the screen without editing, that's for sure! <grin>).

Anyway, take a look, let me know if you (and y'all) might be interested!

Love,

Todd

date: Sat, 27 Feb 2021 11:02:07 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: <opinion@nytimes.com>
subject: Op-Ed: How I didn't become a racist

Body:
**

*How I didn’t become a racist*

*

By Todd McCaffrey, BSME, MFA, SFWA, New York Times Bestselling author

I think it’s important to understand America’s underlying inclination 
toward racism. It doesn’t just come from our parents. It comes from our 
community, our society, from the people we grow up with.

I am an alien, so I think my point of view may be helpful. When I say 
I’m an alien, I’m an alien in Ireland: where I lived for my high school 
and college years. I describe myself as “mid-Atlantic and sinking.”

My journey toward racism started in late elementary and early middle 
school, before I moved to Ireland.

I moved to Long Island, New York, in time to enter third grade. The 
school was small and the community tight-knit. There were only two black 
kids in the whole school — they were brothers, a year apart. Nice guys. 
The younger one had a small bit of iris detached in the white of his eye 
which amazed everyone who saw it.  I remember constantly asking to look 
at it — it was just so cool!

My parents were determined to raise broad-minded children and when the 
chance came, introduced us to people from all  over the world, including 
a Nigerian who stayed the weekend with us, arriving in the marvelously 
bright Nigerian native clothing.

Still, in school hallways, there were the whispers. That blacks would 
beat kids up, that you couldn’t trust them.

This whispering became more apparent in middle school and I think, had 
it not been for my relocation to Ireland, that background whispering 
would have lodged firmly in my mind.

But, barring that lingering underlayer of fear, I like to think that the 
full implant of racism didn’t take with me.  And I think that’s because 
of my time in Ireland… and two people in particular.

In Ireland my classmates said: “I hate all Yanks!” to which was hastily 
added, “But not you, I know you.”  Such statements are examples of 
prejudice and bigotry. It was my first experience of prejudice directed 
at me.

The two people who broke the back of racism for me were strangers.  One 
was a classmate, the other an actor.

We’ll take the second first.  He is Lenny Henry — now SirLenny Henry.  
He is a black comedian. Hearing a very English accent on a black man 
broke the mold that society had tried to impose on me about black people 
— that they all spoke the same.  That was a revelation to me, a “Wait, 
what?” moment. Not all blacks are the same.  My fourteen year-old 
thinking went like this: “So… this notion that blacks are a threat or 
menace… that’s a lie!”

My second revelation came with my classmate, Obudan Obesan. Obudan, for 
me, will always be the primal proof that skin color means 
absolutelynothing!  Also, he proved that James Joyce was a second-rate 
author. I can’t remember when we read Joyce’s The Dubliners.  I’m pretty 
sure it was after I’d first been exposed to Mr. Obesan’s writing.  The 
thing is, Obudan gotthe feel of the Irish, the Dublin Irish, down pat.  
He had it better than Joyce. Waayyybetter than Joyce. Nearly fifty years 
later, my opinion has not changed.

Between Obudan and Sir Lenny Henry, I threw out that notion that black 
people were inferior.

With the benefit of hindsight, I can see how American society has a 
built-in underlying prejudice against people of color.  It starts as the 
whispers in middle grade and high school corridors: “You can’t trust 
them.” “They’ll beat you up.” It’s something that we should be aware of, 
should recognize... and banish.

Because black culture has imbued our society with somuch. Even while we 
derided it, it gave us rock’n’roll, starting with Chuck Berry. The black 
culture is more vibrant and alive than the old, tired white culture. We 
can and should learn a lot from it.  The first step is to recognize 
that. The next step is to embrace this difference, to grasp it and learn 
from it. Our society will grow stronger when we do.

*

date: Tue, 12 May 2020 08:52:51 -0700
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Janis Ian<janisian@earthlink.net>
subject: Hello from Vegas!

Body:
Hi Janis,

I hope you're doing well but I worry about you being in Florida.

I am now 64 (unbelievable!) but it really doesn't feel all that much 
different from 60.

We've been hunkered down -- we self-isolated pretty early as we're all 
high-risk (asthma, diabetes, age, etc.) so we've been holding up just fine.

Who'd'a thunk that face masks would be all the rage in 2020?  Not that 
their efficaciousness is all that great but every little bit helps.

The COVID-19 thing had me pretty rattled for a while but I'm getting 
over it.  Not so much the dying part but just the whole strangeness of 
it all.
It made me realize how lucky we've been in the 20th century.  We'd 
gotten complacent about our health and longevity.  I imagine that's 
going to change.

Anyway, dealing with that slowed me on writing for a bit (also, not 
being able to write in Starbucks).

Do you read Kindle format or do you want PDF or DOC for reading?  I know 
I offered to send you some reading material, I forgot to ask about the 
format.

I've been playing with a bunch of Native Instruments software and 
hardware (picked up their 32-key keyboard, and their cool Maschine pad) 
as well as making art and writing (the all round creative).

Anyway, that's about all the news that's fit to print.
Cheers,
Todd

Message: Hi there, Hope all is well and you are healthy. My name is 
Suzanne Feigenson and I am a Teacher of the Blind and Visually Impaired 
in Las Vegas. We met last year at The Blind Center for our Summer Camp 
Program. Virtual Vision Camp will be May 26-29 and June 1-4, from 
9am-2pm. We are wondering if you would be interested in co-hosting an 
hour long activity/discussion for one of our sessions, each week. (A 
total of 2 sessions. One session with middle school age students and one 
session with high school students). Free to call or email. Looking 
forward to hearing from you. Suzanne
Phone 2: 9734206048

Subject: Millisor Rau

Body:
Hi Lois,

I hope you and yours are doing well in these wild times.

I'm writing because I have a book I started when a friend told me, "My 
sister was drying explosives in the over."

(No, the house did not burn down, surprisingly. The explosives were 
sparklers for a school science project.)

I figured that it was such a good starting premise that I just /had/ to 
write the novel.

Anyway, one of my tertiary characters decided that, as she was going to 
gene-engineer her own child, she would name him from her favorite 
"pre-space" science fiction series.  And so, currently Engisn Millisor 
Rau is serving on HMAS Sparkle (laundry ship for the Navy).  He also 
becomes the OCTO - Officer Candidate Training Officer - for one of my 
heroines, the girl who turned him down when she was a teenager (/Oh, 
damn, the one boy I've ever broke and he's my commanding officer!)/

Obviously, it's an homage on my part.  If it causes you grief, then I 
can change the name but I hope it meets with you approval.

Cheers,

Todd McCaffrey

Subject: The Magpie's War

Body:
Hi!

I hope you're surviving COVID!

As you noticed, we published /The Magpie's War/ and we're very proud of 
it. Brittany, Brianna, and I have been working on this for over four 
years now and we really like it.

Could we send you a copy?

If so, which format would you prefer (we can do paperback or Kindle eBook)?

Cheers,

Todd

date: Mon, 15 Nov 2021 20:42:19 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Todd McCaffrey<todd427@gmail.com>
subject: Fwd: THE KING'S GHOSTS typos, etc. - Chapter 12 - End

Body:
-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	THE KING'S GHOSTS typos, etc. - Chapter 12 - End
Date: 	Mon, 15 Nov 2021 20:16:02 -0800 (PST)
From: 	Susan Silver <ssilver61@comcast.net>
To: 	Todd McCaffrey <todd@toddwriter.com>

Hi Todd,

Here are my observations through the end of the book.

I mentioned previously that the plural of SC is used two different 
ways... either SCs or SC's.  In these remaining chapters, it is written 
both ways. I'm sure you've already addressed this even though it doesn't 
show up in the version I downloaded.  Just throwing this out there since 
I did observe it.

*Chapter12*
Location 4956 - typo... her, not his .../Margaret replied cheerfully, 
bounding out of /her /seat./

Location 5107 - awkward sentence, not sure if you meant to say ./..relay 
a stream of conscious report of an SC that *is* thinking very loudly/ or 
possibly /...relay a stream of conscious report of an SC that *thinks* 
very loudly /or /if it's ...conscious report *to* an SC.../

Location 5147 - typo... I, not If  (*I* believe that it will be more 
meaningful...)

Location 5188 - typo... insert "would" (But what *would* you do in my 
position?)

Location 5217 - typo... Clio, not Cio

Location 5243 - not sure that *nearly* fits here unless it is supposed 
to be *just*. Maybe omit it completely? (...looked to Owami for 
confirmation, but Owami nearly waved her back to Cona).

Location 5347 - typo... on, not off (...co-pilot's hands so that they 
were centered *on* the self-destruct button...)

Location 5425 - "Admirals Branford" isn't correct. Janis is not a 
Branford, but he is an Admiral.

*Chapter 13*
Location 5572 - when onboard the ships, the British word lift is used.  
Actually, I think it works fine.  Just pointing out the use of British 
English.

Location 5588 -  May not be anything but... /You've been requested to go 
TDY to the NWC for the next week./ Not quite sure what this means. Is 
TDY Training Duty?  If so, my mind would read it better as /You've been 
requested to *do* TDY *at* the NWC for the next week./  Maybe this is 
how they speak and my non-military mind just has problems.

Location 5739 - Comma needed for If/then sentence: /Because if she were 
picked*,***it'd mean that.../

Location 5817 - typo... planted, not planet (...and by whom that 
bacterial assault was *planted* on Sparkle)

Location 5858 - typo... Rochelle, not Rachel

Location 5935 - Insert "said"... Fromer *said* as he strolled...

*Chapter 14*
Location 5962: typo... The, not They (*The* four of them fit..)

*Chapter 15*
Location 6488: tonnes - is it British for tons? (...there's /tonnes/ 
we're not seeing). I may have seen this somewhere else, but not sure if 
it was in this book or the first one, /Raw Space/.

Location 6724 - is this a typo... she, not he or is there someone else 
Owami is referring to? (She didn't want to joggle the Major's arm while 
*she* was conducing the assault...)

Location 6744 - typo... her, not him (Cona sent in *her* first team...)

Location 6772 - typo... her, not his (/Clip/, Cona ordered and *her* 
reserve squad moved out...)

Location 6824 - typo... outsider should be plural (... the name used 
with *outsiders* for /The King's Own Ghosts...)/

*Chapter 16*
Location 6966 (2nd paragraph of chapter) - This is a very long sentence. 
Suggestions: 1) move the comma from before to after "Scotty" and 2)  
drop the "when" along with the comma and put a period after Munchkin

Location 7032 - typo... on, not own ("So put her *on* alert," Rochelle 
said.)

Location 7088 - same confusing working for me: ...cadets were with us 
TDY to the NWC...  Guess it's just me.

Location 7159 - typo... Morton has a "w" on the end

*Chapter 17*
Location 7227 - typo whether, not when (... hard pressed to say 
*whether* her bedmate was male, female, or something else.)

Location 7244 - The math doesn't work. If Neff's sun is 700,000 times 
larger than Canaris Prime, it would be 14 million km in diameter, not 
1.4 km.  For 1.4 million km diameter, it would only be 70,000 times 
larger. (FYI - I did not check the mass calculations.)

Location 7279 - 1) typo... *Ophelia* is not possessive and 2) delete 
"said even" (...kneeling down to Ophelia's said even as she hit...)

That's all I have for you Todd.  Hope I didn't get this to you too late.
Susan

from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Monique Bucheger<monique.bucheger@gmail.com>
subject: Re: Trouble Blows West

Body:
Hi Monique,

Thank you for your patience, I read Trouble Blows West.

It did not work for me.  Permit me to emphasize, it did not work for *me.*
*
*
Here's why the book didn't work for me:

Ginny's character just didn't seem real to me.  It became less so as the 
book progressed. Her mounting anger and vengeance didn't have any 
rational background to support them and her unwillingness to listen to 
reason or learn finally killed any sympathy I might have had for her.

I also questioned the setting -- was this in the 1970s? 80s? 90s? 
Earlier? Later?

Ginny's love for her mare didn't work for me. I grew up with horse mad 
girls, and Ginny didn't fit.  It seemed to me that her horse was at 
about the same level in her affections as a rusted hand-me-down bicycle.

I began to notice the number of chapters.  There's an *awful* lot of them.

I also wasn't sure about the farm -- was it a cattle farm? Dairy? Crop? 
Mixed use?  That question nagged at me and helped pull me out of the book.

Cheers,
Todd McCaffrey

P.S.: The YA/Middle Grade books that I read include:

Ally Carter's /The Gallagher Girls/ 
<https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000S1LF5K>
also Ally Carter's Winterborne Home for Vengeance and Valor 
<https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B07T4HQR9D>
Alan Bradley started a marvelous series about an eleven year-old sleuth 
with The Sweetness at the Bottom of the Pie 
<https://www.amazon.com/dp/B0027G6XDS>
L.A. Meyer produced the amazing Bloody Jack 
<https://www.amazon.com/dp/B003K16PPU> series.
Also, Carlos Hernandez knocked it out of the park with Sal and Gabi 
Break the Universe <https://www.amazon.com/dp/B07FL82MKG> which is 
currently an Amazon #1 Best Seller

date: Sat, 27 Feb 2021 11:02:07 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: <opinion@nytimes.com>
subject: Op-Ed: How I didn't become a racist

Body:
**

*How I didn’t become a racist*

*

By Todd McCaffrey, BSME, MFA, SFWA, New York Times Bestselling author

I think it’s important to understand America’s underlying inclination 
toward racism. It doesn’t just come from our parents. It comes from our 
community, our society, from the people we grow up with.

I am an alien, so I think my point of view may be helpful. When I say 
I’m an alien, I’m an alien in Ireland: where I lived for my high school 
and college years. I describe myself as “mid-Atlantic and sinking.”

My journey toward racism started in late elementary and early middle 
school, before I moved to Ireland.

I moved to Long Island, New York, in time to enter third grade. The 
school was small and the community tight-knit. There were only two black 
kids in the whole school — they were brothers, a year apart. Nice guys. 
The younger one had a small bit of iris detached in the white of his eye 
which amazed everyone who saw it.  I remember constantly asking to look 
at it — it was just so cool!

My parents were determined to raise broad-minded children and when the 
chance came, introduced us to people from all  over the world, including 
a Nigerian who stayed the weekend with us, arriving in the marvelously 
bright Nigerian native clothing.

Still, in school hallways, there were the whispers. That blacks would 
beat kids up, that you couldn’t trust them.

This whispering became more apparent in middle school and I think, had 
it not been for my relocation to Ireland, that background whispering 
would have lodged firmly in my mind.

But, barring that lingering underlayer of fear, I like to think that the 
full implant of racism didn’t take with me.  And I think that’s because 
of my time in Ireland… and two people in particular.

In Ireland my classmates said: “I hate all Yanks!” to which was hastily 
added, “But not you, I know you.”  Such statements are examples of 
prejudice and bigotry. It was my first experience of prejudice directed 
at me.

The two people who broke the back of racism for me were strangers.  One 
was a classmate, the other an actor.

We’ll take the second first.  He is Lenny Henry — now SirLenny Henry.  
He is a black comedian. Hearing a very English accent on a black man 
broke the mold that society had tried to impose on me about black people 
— that they all spoke the same.  That was a revelation to me, a “Wait, 
what?” moment. Not all blacks are the same.  My fourteen year-old 
thinking went like this: “So… this notion that blacks are a threat or 
menace… that’s a lie!”

My second revelation came with my classmate, Obudan Obesan. Obudan, for 
me, will always be the primal proof that skin color means 
absolutelynothing!  Also, he proved that James Joyce was a second-rate 
author. I can’t remember when we read Joyce’s The Dubliners.  I’m pretty 
sure it was after I’d first been exposed to Mr. Obesan’s writing.  The 
thing is, Obudan gotthe feel of the Irish, the Dublin Irish, down pat.  
He had it better than Joyce. Waayyybetter than Joyce. Nearly fifty years 
later, my opinion has not changed.

Between Obudan and Sir Lenny Henry, I threw out that notion that black 
people were inferior.

With the benefit of hindsight, I can see how American society has a 
built-in underlying prejudice against people of color.  It starts as the 
whispers in middle grade and high school corridors: “You can’t trust 
them.” “They’ll beat you up.” It’s something that we should be aware of, 
should recognize... and banish.

Because black culture has imbued our society with somuch. Even while we 
derided it, it gave us rock’n’roll, starting with Chuck Berry. The black 
culture is more vibrant and alive than the old, tired white culture. We 
can and should learn a lot from it.  The first step is to recognize 
that. The next step is to embrace this difference, to grasp it and learn 
from it. Our society will grow stronger when we do.

*

Hi Diana (and all),

I just wanted to check to be certain that Grim Oak Press has the rights 
to do a special edition of Dragonflight. 
<https://grimoakpress.com/collections/limited-editions/products/dragonflight-limited-edition>

Shawn Speakman seems to be a really nice guy (was diagnosed with 
non-Hodgkin’s lymphoma in 2011) but he's bobbled on contracts with me 
(I'm not too worried, he might just have dropped the ball) but just to 
be certain, I wanted to make sure that he was all "right and tight" with 
you on the contract end (he's got me doing the introduction).

Cheers,

Todd

date: Tue, 12 May 2020 08:52:51 -0700
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Janis Ian<janisian@earthlink.net>
subject: Hello from Vegas!

Body:
Hi Janis,

I hope you're doing well but I worry about you being in Florida.

I am now 64 (unbelievable!) but it really doesn't feel all that much 
different from 60.

We've been hunkered down -- we self-isolated pretty early as we're all 
high-risk (asthma, diabetes, age, etc.) so we've been holding up just fine.

Who'd'a thunk that face masks would be all the rage in 2020?  Not that 
their efficaciousness is all that great but every little bit helps.

The COVID-19 thing had me pretty rattled for a while but I'm getting 
over it.  Not so much the dying part but just the whole strangeness of 
it all.
It made me realize how lucky we've been in the 20th century.  We'd 
gotten complacent about our health and longevity.  I imagine that's 
going to change.

Anyway, dealing with that slowed me on writing for a bit (also, not 
being able to write in Starbucks).

Do you read Kindle format or do you want PDF or DOC for reading?  I know 
I offered to send you some reading material, I forgot to ask about the 
format.

I've been playing with a bunch of Native Instruments software and 
hardware (picked up their 32-key keyboard, and their cool Maschine pad) 
as well as making art and writing (the all round creative).

Anyway, that's about all the news that's fit to print.
Cheers,
Todd

date: Tue, 08 Mar 2022 11:35:53 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Angel Adams<angelinasvista@gmail.com>
subject: Audio Work

Body:
Hi Angel!

So... there are two projects:

1. Cloud Conqueror (Twin Soul Series #2)

2. The Jupiter Game (that's me)

The idea is:

1. Convert from manuscript to "screenplay" (really, radio play-ish) format.

2. Create audio suitable for ACX.

I've already done a full audiobook with ELLAY (and it's making money!!) 
which is why I think this might be a good idea.

I'm willing to pay for the conversion, the output to be in FinalDraft 12 
format (.fdx) but, of course, if I think the price is too high, I'll do 
it myself.

For the audio stuff, the going rate is $250 PFH (per finished hour) 
which, quite simply, I can't afford (which is why I was the sole voice 
for ELLAY). However, perhaps a royalty share?

You can get a 30-day trial of FinalDraft here <https://finaldraft.com/>. 
After that, if things work out, I might include the cost of you getting 
it in our deal.

Attached are the 1 page original and 1 page script format to give you an 
idea of what I want.  The way I handle it, I create SIDES so that I can 
read each voice separately, then the "general description" is what I 
read as the narrator. (You wouldn't want to go from the "screenplay" 
that I produce to the screen without editing, that's for sure! <grin>).

Anyway, take a look, let me know if you (and y'all) might be interested!

Love,

Todd

Would you like to read the sequel, The King's Ghosts?

I've got it ready in ALPHA.

-- Todd

P.S.: I'm going to do delivery with Bookfunnel which should be easier.

from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Gigi<gigi@pernhome.com>
subject: I'm buying a Tesla!

Body:
HI Squeej,

I decided that I needed to go electric, so I'm buying a Tesla.

I've already ordered the car but I had an issue with their website so I 
went to the store and got that sorted.  While there, I also arranged a 
test drive. Whoo-ee! WHAT a beautiful piece of technology!  Much better 
pickup than the Prius and better stopping, too.

I'm thrilled!

In other news, our book, /The Magpie's War/, will be released on Monday. 
We're really thrilled with it.

Love,

Todd

date: Sun, 22 Aug 2021 11:29:54 -0700
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Todd McCaffrey<todd427@gmail.com>
subject: Fwd: How's it going?

Body:
-------- Forwarded Message --------
Subject: 	Re: How's it going?
Date: 	Sun, 22 Aug 2021 06:03:07 +0100
From: 	Georgeanne Kennedy <squeej51g@gmail.com>
To: 	todd <todd@toddwriter.com>

Ah, sweetie! It’s lovely of you to check in, and probably couldn’t come 
at a better time.
You asked, so I ain’t gonna hold back. Tune in your big brother 
listening ears cause your baby sister needs sound advice. I have to 
admit, I’m not doing too well. Wish I could fluff away, all light and 
breezy, and tell you ‘I’m grand’ but I’m not. I guess it’s a combination 
of things but, predominantly, living on my own, away from the area I’ve 
known for over 40 years, is incredibly hard and seems to magnify any 
other difficult issues I experience in my life as a single 60-something. 
It’s like I’m starting all over again, when I’m already starting over 
again since my marriage ended. The property market here is a mess, with 
houses selling far above asking price because there’s a scarcity of 
stock for sale, so I can’t afford to buy anything now and lay down new 
roots. The holding pattern I’m in is excruciating!

And I guess other aspects of my life, and the seemingly never-ending 
crises that are engulfing the earth, are all mixing together to fill my 
plate with a gloomy looking repast. I should stop reading the news.

Sleep is difficult; I’ve been wide awake for an hour and it’s not yet 
5am, so this day’s store of resilience is already fecked up. - I have to 
go to Owen’s girlfriend’s place today to help celebrate the “gender 
reveal” (slap me quick before I gag!) they have planned now that their 
gestating baby is 3 months along. It’ll be the first time I’ll be in the 
same air space as Geoff since we were in court getting our divorce 
decree; when I bawled my eyes out in front of everyone whilst giving 
testimony. Oy! Added to that, Owen has, frankly, been treating me like a 
piece of shit over the last few months so the strain is telling. I’ll be 
a big girl, though, go along to see what sex the baby will be and try to 
smile a lot.

About two weeks ago Geoff’s youngest sister, Edel, the main carer for my 
(ex?) mother-in-law, Joan, was in a terrible car crash while travelling 
to Cork for a weekend break with her boyfriend. She’s broken the bones 
in the top of her foot, and two vertebrae just above the tailbone. She 
literally broke her arse. Poor Mick, her boyfriend, is far worse off and 
will remain in hospital in Cork for at least another 6 weeks, undergoing 
another couple of surgeries on top of the 3 he’s already had. Fuck! What 
a nightmare, and no visitors allowed to see him. Poor guy.

And then a totally strange series of things have occurred recently with 
regard to my late sister-in-law’s husband, Noel. He’s a very successful 
businessman and a pub owner and has been trying to cope with the sudden 
death of his wife in June 2019, along with the grief their two (young) 
adult kids are experiencing, plus the lack of pub business due to Covid.

I’ve kept in loose touch with Noel ever since he asked me to write and 
deliver Maria’s eulogy. Over the last couple of years, through texts, 
he’s always suggested that we get together for a drink and catch up 
which I’ve always put down as pure politeness. Recently he suggested the 
same thing but in a phone call when he told me about Edel’s crash, which 
no one else in the Kennedy clan had informed me of.

Edel has always been close to Noel and she asked him to drive to Cork to 
be with her whilst she gave an official report to the Gardai regarding 
the crash. So here’s where it gets weird, Tig. Noel asked me to drive 
with him to Cork to collect Edel but suggested we go down the day before 
her release, have a nice meal, a few drinks and “a laugh”, and stay the 
night in an hotel before we retrieve Edel the following day. Whilst he 
was suggesting this plan I was uncommonly quiet on the other end of the 
phone and Noel said we would, of course, have separate rooms because he 
“wasn’t going to try and climb into bed with me”. The thought never 
crossed my mind! To be honest, I wasn’t sure what the fuck was going on 
but it’s been a very long time since I’ve been in the company of a kind 
man who wanted to hang out with me, so I agreed, thinking what harm 
could come of it.

At any rate, as it turned out, Edel didn’t have to have an interview 
with the Gardai in Cork and without discussing it with me, Noel changed 
his initial plan ‘to have a laugh’, and we simply drove to and from Cork 
on the same day to collect Edel. I reckon he possibly had a good think 
about what he’d proposed and decided against it. We had a pleasant time 
talking on the way down to Cork but I couldn’t forget the fact that I’m 
fairly certain he’d possibly made a pass at me. Or did he? I have no clue.

So my silly girl head can’t stop thinking about this, and Noel. In fact, 
it’s wrecking my head, and living alone doesn’t help; I already spend 
*way* too much time in my own head. I keep scolding myself to stop! but 
I’m lonely, and would like a man to like me again. I guess I’m just 
going to have to let time do it’s magical thing and allow it all to 
slowly fade away. Talk to me, Todd. Give me your take on this. Sorry 
this is so long but, hell! I’m long-winded.

Love,
Skin

Sent from my iPad

I am /so sorry/ that you are having to deal with constant calls from

date: Tue, 07 Dec 2021 22:55:11 -0800
from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Georgeanne Kennedy<squeej51g@gmail.com>
subject: Catching up

Body:
Hi Squeej,

I see from the Irish Times that you're all being inundated.  I hope it's 
not too bad. Curiously enough, it's raining here in Vegas.

We've survived Channukah although I still have more gifts to give (so 
we'll get them out nearly to Xmas).

Dex tells me that he's taking Russian 102 next semester and a bunch of 
other stuff.

I binge watched "I am not okay with this" which, it turns out, Dex had 
recommended but I'd forgotten.

20BooksTo50k Vegas was a lot of fun, the first time I've been out for a bit.

I've slowed down a bit on my Canaris Rift series, had to stop and 
re-read everything and make notes so that I knew where I was in terms of 
equipment and all.

I also binge watched the 3rd season of the new Lost In Space which I 
quite enjoyed.  I've been following Hawkeye on Disney. In addition, I 
discovered "A Boy Called Christmas" which is now among my favorite 
all-time Xmas stories.

I hope you're doing well.

Love,

Todd

from: todd<todd@toddwriter.com>
to: Brit Winner<bybritwinner@gmail.com>, Brianna Winner<briannarosewinner@gmail.com>
subject: Happy Birthday!

Body:
And, in my tradition of annoying you with horoscopes, I present you with 
this:

        ByHoliday Mathis <https://www.creators.com/author/holiday-mathis>

PISCES (Feb. 19-March 20). You want a clear instruction for the current 
problem, but if the universe were really to thunder from the clouds 
saying, "Do this!" you'd rebel and tell it to stop bossing you around. 
So try to read and heed the signs.

TODAY'S BIRTHDAY (March 1). Applying your talents for the betterment of 
your family, friends and community will be at the forefront in your 
goals. With a concentrated and practiced regiment, progress becomes 
apparent. You'll love where discipline takes you, but build plenty of 
rewards, breaks and leisure into your life to avoid burnout. Cancer and 
Scorpio adore you. Your lucky numbers are: 9, 2, 22, 10 and 13.

Love ya! :)

Todd
